body:
Hey Trevor,

Honestly, I think that extendable should be the default behavior (I thought it was)! So, if everyone agrees, +1 for making it the default and we do not even need a configuration option. across_browser should also be the default. For example, gmail works this way and I would consider it an application that should have strong security concerns.

Abou tests, I recommend you to run just `rake test` for this while, since Datamapper tests are not green (yet). All them pass here if the ORM is ActiveRecord.

I'm +1  for this kind of behavior being default, but I know some people are very... umm... sensitive about security so I thought I'd make it opt-in :)

I'm still not able to get the tests running today:

http://pastie.org/1016179

I think I'm just in a funny spot with Rails/Devise changes, but if everything looks like it's passing to you, that's fine with me and I can just try again later.
Oh, so I should have said - I'm happy to do more work on this issue if/when you'd like. I'll keep an eye on this ticket. Thank you!
About your tests, please update your devise repo and be sure to be using latest rails! This error is happening because you may not be using latest Rails from the Gemfile!

I'm pretty sure I'm using the latest Rails and Devise... I must be doing something else wrong, but I don't know what! :)

It's no big deal - I'll see if I can track it down when the Rails RC is out or something like that. I was able to run the tests around this remember_for_extendable stuff I did last night, so I think that's in the clear at least.

Hey mate, so +1 for adding both configuration options. There are a few changes I would like to propose though:

1) I would like to discuss a better name than remember_for_extendable. I think the current name is not very clear in intent. Something like extend_remember_on_access or extend_remember_period sounds better;

2) remember_me_across_browsers should be on by default :)

3) I believe that in your current patch, the feature you added does not work. We would need to add some integration tests. You are relying on the remember_me! call, but that only happens when the user signs in through password authentication (notice Devise::Hooks::Rememberable is only added to Devise::Strategies::Authenticatable).

http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/blob/07a1b0e3f4bf4fe9d6fe0a9dd48ebf94ffde5b58/lib/devise/hooks/rememberable.rb

Since the Rememberable strategy does not inherit from Authenticatable (http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/blob/07a1b0e3f4bf4fe9d6fe0a9dd48ebf94ffde5b58/lib/devise/strategies/rememberable.rb#L9), whenever signing in through the remember me token, it's never renewed.

My suggestion is: include the rememberable hook in the rememberable strategy and overwrite the remember_me? implementation to only be called if the user has remember_me_extendable set to true.

Great work!
OK - thanks for the pointers, and I'm sorry I didn't get it right the first time :) I'll give it another go like you said and report back here when I have something to show. Thank you!

OK - I have some commits in this branch that accomplish "remember across browsers" as I named it. Feel free to change the naming, or I can change it to something else if you like, but I thought this was good. I tried to test the possibilities fully for this, but maybe it's too much testing - I'm not sure. 

http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/commits/remember_me_across_browsers

I'm going to try the second part in a branch based on this, but I'm a little worried because I can't get the tests passing, as mentioned here:

http://github.com/plataformatec/devise/issues#issue/352

I'll update here again when I get extend_remember_on_access (or whatever we name it) working as best as I can. 

Thanks!

[edit]

Here's my first try at the extend remember feature:

http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/commits/extend_try_1

I'm not sure I like the implementation this way. I tried the way you suggested and ran into some testing problems, but I'm having trouble testing this way as well. I was thinking that the remember me extension might be fine to run just if a user is remembered (as opposed to signing in on a different browser). 

Feedback is welcome, but I'll just give it another shot when it's not so late at night in any case :)
Hey Trevor, I merged the remember me across browser. Now I will check the extendable feature. :) Thanks!
Hey Trevor, I do like your implementation of extendable. Which issues are you facing with testing? Your model tests looks great, we just need to write a few integration ones.

That's great! :)

I tried to do some integration tests for the extendable stuff, but I guess I don't understand how it's supposed to work. Maybe you can provide an example, or if you'd rather just go ahead and make the necessary tests - either way is fine. Here's what I tried:

http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/commit/5bf7abba2f8813e8ca0efac42b4c917f620c0778#L4R49

...but it's not working as I expected. 

The way I did the implementation, extend_remember_me_token! is called every time the user is remembered. If config.extend_remember_token_on_access is false, it'll just return, so it would be fine to call every time. So, I thought one test that ensures the method is called after a user is remembered would be enough -- since the method is well tested. Maybe another test to ensure the method is not called if the user is not remembered would also be good, but I didn't get to that. 

So, my first test isn't working the way I thought it would. I think the implementation is working -- I've browser tested it. Maybe you can take a look? Thank you!
Just one question, are you using mocks to test it?
Yeah, you can see in the commit line in my last comment. It should take you to the test, which is using .expects. Is that the problem?

Sorry, I missed the integration test in the commit above.

The user (the object instance) you are accessing in the test, is _not_ the same which is brought by rememberable strategy and which the extend_remember_me_token! token is called (although they represent the same row in the database). In general, is not a good idea to use mocks in integration/acceptance tests. You always need to be in the mindset of the person in front of the browser.

Notice you already tested all the possible conditions in models tests, so the integration tests are just a sanity check. In pseudo code, I would do something like this:

```
test "not extending my period" do
  create_user
  store_user_remember_token_in_cookie
  visit user_protected_path
  assert_logged_in_with_success
  assert_no_new_cookie_is_sent_back
  sign_out
end

test "extending my period" do
  swap Devise, :extend_remember_me_token => true do
    create_user
    store_user_remember_token_in_cookie
    visit user_protected_path
    assert_logged_in_with_success
    assert_a_cookie_with_a_new_expire_date_but_the_same_token
  end
end
```

I think there are already a few helpers that already do create_user & store_user_remember_token_in_cookie.
I edited the comment above. :) Just in case you already checked it.

OK - I wasn't able to figure out how to test with cookies as you suggested, but I think I did get some reasonable tests passing. You'd want to look at the following 2 commits:

http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/commit/5bf7abba2f8813e8ca0efac42b4c917f620c0778

http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/commit/7908413fa849aa6483a6d56de3e93dafb6188ed9

...from this branch:

http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/commits/extend_try_1

The second commit has the new integration tests. 

I had to modify the create_user_and_remember method and I'm checking that the remember token expiration has been extended somewhat forcefully using to_s because I was getting some weird Time comparison problems. The merge commit in the branch is so that I had a green test suite from your master branch. 

Anyway - I think this might be good enough to pull now. Please let me know what you think. I'm happy to make any more changes that you like, and I'm sorry this has been a bit of a pain for you!
This has not been a pain for me at all! :) I will check these new commits druing this week and let you know! Cheers and thanks!
Awesome! I'm going to be gone on vacation for a week, so apologies in advance if it takes me some time to get back to you. Thanks again!
Yes, tests looks better! But you still need to resend the cookie, because it has expire date in it as well. :) I will try to play with it later as well.
Add extend_remember_period, closed by 058d433f281ce32443e607b6bcd356b2189761c2.
Hey mate, I was without electricity the whole morning today, so I decided to tackle this issue. The bad news is that I could not use your stuff. Sorry! :(

Awesome! Thank you so much for working on this again. I'm really sorry I wasn't able to get it all working, and I really appreciate you tackling the issue. 

I looked it over, and the only thing I wanted to note was a small documentation issue. I can work up a quick patch if you like, but it's just syncing these two comments:

http://github.com/plataformatec/devise/commit/058d433f281ce32443e607b6bcd356b2189761c2#L3R67

and

http://github.com/plataformatec/devise/commit/058d433f281ce32443e607b6bcd356b2189761c2#L0R100

I was thinking they both should say the same thing, and not use the word "signup" since that might be confusing. Maybe something like:

"When true, extends the user's remember period when they are remembered via cookie."

Anyway, I'm happy to work up a patch if that's easier for you - just let me know.
A patch for docs would be welcome! It seems I forgot to add docs to the model as well! :(
OK - I'll put something together now.

OK - I think this should cover everything:

http://github.com/trevorturk/devise/commit/2bcfdcfb802ecd3472b14ed99d5502ab4318a5ba

Let me know if there's anything wrong, missing, or could be improved. Thanks again!
